Follow up after an ectopic pregnancy
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I follow up a woman after treatment for an ectopic pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ensure that arrangements for routine antenatal care are cancelled (if they have begun).
  • Give the woman the opportunity to discuss any questions she has about the ectopic pregnancy, including the risk of recurrence and the effect on future fertility. Be aware that:
    • The rate of recurrence of ectopic pregnancy is about 18.5%. 
    • About 64–76% of women who have had an ectopic pregnancy are able to have a subsequent spontaneous intrauterine pregnancy.
    • In women with no history of subfertility or tubal pathology, there is no difference in the rate of fertility, the risk of future tubal ectopic pregnancy, or tubal patency rates between the different treatment methods. 
    • In women with a previous history of subfertility, treatment with expectant or medical management is associated with improved reproductive outcomes compared with radical surgery.
    • Following treatment with methotrexate, there is no effect on ovarian reserve. 
    • In women who have undergone treatment with uterine artery embolisation and systemic methotrexate for non-tubal ectopic pregnancies, live births have been reported in subsequent pregnancies.
    • In women undergoing laparoscopic management of ovarian pregnancies, future fertility prospects are good. 
  • Assess the woman's psychological well-being, and offer counselling if appropriate.
    • Advise the woman on how to access support via patient support groups, such as the Ectopic Pregnancy Trust, or local bereavement counselling services.
    • Be aware that:
      • Grief, anxiety, and depression are common following pregnancy loss.
      • Grief following pregnancy loss is comparable in nature, intensity, and duration to grief reactions in people suffering other types of major loss.
      • Distress is commonly at its worst 4–6 weeks after pregnancy loss and may last 6–12 months.
  • Advise the woman that she should inform her GP as soon a possible about any future pregnancy so that an ultrasound scan can be arranged at 6–7 weeks to establish the location and viability of the pregnancy.
  • Give appropriate contraception advice, including that:
    • A history of ectopic pregnancy is not a contraindication to any form of hormonal or intrauterine contraception. See the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment for more information.
    • All methods of contraception protect against ectopic pregnancy by reducing overall pregnancy rates. However, in the event of contraception failure, the risk of ectopic pregnancy will depend on the method of contraception used. See the section on Causes and risk factors for more information.
    • Reliable contraception should be used for at least 3 months after treatment with methotrexate for an ectopic pregnancy, as there is a possible teratogenic risk due to the prolonged effects of methotrexate.
  • Ensure that all rhesus-negative women who have had surgical removal of an ectopic pregnancy have received anti-D immunoglobulin. 
    • Be aware that anti-D immunoglobulin should not be given to women who:
      • Receive solely medical management for an ectopic pregnancy.  
      • Have a pregnancy of unknown location.
  • Provide additional information on ectopic pregnancy and ectopic pregnancy support groups. For example:
    • The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG) has produced a patient information leaflet on ectopic pregnancy.
    • NHS has useful information on Ectopic pregnancy.
    • The Ectopic Pregnancy Trust and Miscarriage Association have several leaflets on ectopic pregnancy.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage: Diagnosis and initial management [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012; NICE, 2012] and the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG) guideline Diagnosis and Management of Ectopic Pregnancy [Elson, 2016].

Cancelling routine antenatal care
  • This recommendation is pragmatic and is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Giving the woman the opportunity to discuss any questions she has about ectopic pregnancy, and providing easily accessible information
  • The NICE guideline development group (GDG) identified support and information giving as one of the priorities for implementation in managing women with an ectopic pregnancy [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012; NICE, 2012].
    • The NICE GDG recommends that throughout the woman's care, she and (with agreement) her partner should be given specific evidence-based information (in a variety of formats), including information on what to do if she becomes pregnant again, the likely impact of her treatment on future fertility, and where to access support and counselling services.
Rate of recurrence of ectopic pregnancy
  • The RCOG identified several studies comparing surgical management, medical and surgical management, and surgical and expectant management of ectopic pregnancy. There were no statistical differences in the rate of recurrent ectopic pregnancy, and most long-term follow-up studies quoted a recurrence rate of around 18.5% [Elson, 2016].
Effect on future fertility
  • The general information on future fertility is based on the RCOG guideline [Elson, 2016].
    • The GDG of the RCOG guideline based these recommendations largely on evidence from non-analytical studies (for example case reports and case-series); extrapolated evidence from well-conducted case–control or cohort studies with a low risk of confounding, bias, or chance and a moderate probability that the relationship is causal; and on their expert opinion.
    • For more information, see the RCOG guideline on Diagnosis and Management of Ectopic Pregnancy.
  • The information on the rate of intrauterine pregnancy after treatment for an ectopic pregnancy is based on evidence from studies identified by CKS (and included in the RCOG guideline).
    • A randomized controlled trial found that the 2-year rate of an intrauterine pregnancy after treatment for an ectopic pregnancy was 64–71% depending on the treatment used [Fernandez, 2013].
    • An observational population based-study reported similar results (67–76% depending on the treatment used) [de Bennetot, 2012].
Assessing the woman's psychological well-being 
  • This recommendation is based on the NICE guideline Ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012] and on: 
    • Expert opinion that the psychological effect of an ectopic pregnancy is often overlooked, as an ectopic pregnancy may not be viewed in the same way as other pregnancy loss [Tay et al, 2000].
    • Expert opinion that women who have had an ectopic pregnancy may have a similar grief reaction to women experiencing miscarriage, but also have the added stress of a potential reduction in fertility [Tay et al, 2000].
    • Extrapolated evidence on the prevalence and severity of psychological distress following miscarriage [Brier, 1999; Brier, 2004; Brier, 2008].
  • The recommendation that the woman should be made aware of how to access support via patient support groups or local bereavement counselling services is based on the RCOG guideline and is based on extrapolated evidence from well-controlled case-control and/or cohort studies [RCOG, 2016]. 
Managing future pregnancies
  • This recommendation is based on the expert opinion of the previous expert reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • In addition, the NICE guideline on ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage states that women who have had an ectopic pregnancy should be informed that they can self-refer to an early pregnancy assessment service in future pregnancies if they have any early concerns [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012].
Contraception advice
  • The advice that a history of ectopic pregnancy is not a contraindication to any form of hormonal or intrauterine contraception is based on the UK Medical Eligibility Criteria for contraceptive use published by the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) [FSRH, 2016] and the Medical eligibility for contraceptive use published by the World Health Organization (WHO) [WHO, 2015].
  • The advice that reliable contraception should be used for at least 3 months following treatment with methotrexate for an ectopic pregnancy is based on the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics (SPC) [ABPI, 2017] and the RCOG guideline [RCOG, 2016].
Ensuring that anti-D immunoglobulin has been given where appropriate
  • The NICE GDG reviewed the evidence for anti-D rhesus prophylaxis for women with an ectopic pregnancy [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012].
    • Although the quality of the evidence was very low, the NICE GDG felt that, taken as a whole, there was evidence of a risk of sensitization for women if they did not receive anti-D rhesus prophylaxis following a therapeutic abortion.
    • The NICE GDG was informed that the chance of sensitization increases when there is a greater likelihood of mixing between the maternal and fetal blood, such as during surgical removal of an ectopic pregnancy. For this reason, the GDG recommends that all rhesus-negative women who have had surgical removal of an ectopic pregnancy should receive anti-D rhesus prophylaxis.
    • Based on their clinical experience, the NICE GDG considered the risk of significant fetal and maternal blood mixing following treatment with methotrexate to be low and therefore does not recommend anti-D rhesus prophylaxis in this case.
